context: In Volos, the NO2 levels seem to be lower during spring and summer months than during fall and winter months, especially during midday and afternoon hours, while in Patras there is not a substantial difference between spring-summer and fall-winter NO2 concentrations. Regarding the pollutants’ diurnal patterns, it is interesting that, in the city of Volos, NO, NO2, SO2 and CO, exhibit the typical urban daily pattern of primary air pollutants characterized by two peaks, one in the morning and one late in evening, mainly during the fall-winter months, coinciding apparently with the town activities (traffic, open market hours and central heating). The relatively lower daytime concentrations of SO2, in the city of Volos, compared to those of Patras, would be attributed, besides perhaps the difference in emissions, to the relatively higher oxidation of SO2 to sulfate ( SO 4 2 - )—under the effect of solar radiation—and to the observed higher ozone concentration, and probably to OH (Harrison and Perry, 1986). Khoder’s (2002) results show that the oxidation processes and conversion of SO2 to sulfate and of NO2 to nitrate (NO3), depend on the photochemical oxidation and that the sulfur conversion ratio increases with increasing ozone concentration. The higher ozone concentrations in Volos, compared to those in Patras, may contribute to the higher conversion ratio of sulfur in Volos than in Patras, where higher values of SO2 were observed. The different rates of SO2 oxidation between the two cities may partially explain the descent of SO2 in Volos during midday hours, when ozone is quite high, leading in a substantially different pattern in comparison to that in Patras, where the lower ozone levels allow increased SO2 concentrations during midday hours. Besides that reason, the more frequent ship calls in the very busy harbor of Patras and the heavy commercial trucks and articulated lorries which call the harbor, probably lead to the SO2 accumulation during the daytime hours and cause this different pattern.
